questions.question: A 3-year-old child is brought to the emergency department after a sudden pull on their arm. The child is holding their right arm close to their body and refuses to move it. There is tenderness over the radial head but no swelling or deformity. What is the most likely arm position in this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Flexed and pronated Explanation: The condition indicates a pulled elbow (nursemaid’s elbow) caused by a sudden pull on the arm, leading to radial head subluxation. The classic arm position is slightly flexed and pronated. Pulled Elbow (also known as Nursemaid’s Elbow) Age group 1-5 years (most common) Mechanism of injury A sudden jerk or pull on the arm when it is extended and pronated causes the radial head to slip out of the annular ligament (radial head subluxation). Clinical presentation The child holds the affected arm close to the body in a slightly flexed and pronated position, resisting movement, particularly supination. X-ray Diagnosis is usually clinical. X-ray is unnecessary unless there is suspicion of other injuries. It may appear normal If visible, they can show subtle displacement of the radial head , with the possible elevation of the anterior fat pad or visibility of the posterior fat pad, indicating joint effusion. Treatment Reduction of the subluxation by supination and flexion or hyperpronation of the forearm typically results in immediate relief.

questions.question: Match the following epiphyseal centres with their respective ages based on their appearance. 1. Capitulum a. 4 years 2. Radial head b. 8 years 3. Medial epicondyle c. 2 years 4. Trochlea appears d. 6 years
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 1-c, 2-a, 3-d, 4-b Explanation: The appearance of the epiphyseal centres around the elbow joint with their respective ages is given below, Epiphyseal centers Age of Appearance Capitulum 2 years Radial head 4 years Medial epicondyle 6 years Trochlea 8 years Olecranon 10 years Lateral epicondyle 12 years Mnemonic: CRETOL Reference: Apley and Solomon’s System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th Edition, Page 385.

questions.question: A 35-year-old male fell from a height of about 6 feet while carrying a heavy load, landing on his left side and bracing himself with his left arm. Upon examination, there is a visible deformity in the mid-forearm region, and the elbow is swollen. Given the X-ray findings, what is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Monteggia Explanation: The presented scenario and the X-ray findings indicating a fracture of the upper third of the ulna indicate a Monteggia fracture, also called a treacherous fracture. While the ulna fracture is clearly evident on the X-ray, the associated dislocation of the radial head may be overlooked. Monteggia fracture Site Fracture of the proximal third of the ulna is accompanied by a radial head dislocation . Cause Fall on an outstretched hand Mechanism Complications Nerve injury (Posterior Interosseous Nerve) Malunion Non-union Cubitus valgus. Radio ulnar synostosis (Type 4 Monteggia Fracture) Myositis Ossificans. Galeazzi fracture (Option B) involves a fracture of the distal half of the radius , accompanied by a dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint. Galeazzi fracture Essex Lopresti fracture (Option C) involves a fracture of the radial head along with a dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint. Nightstick fracture (Option D) is characterised by an isolated fracture of the ulna , commonly resulting from a direct blow. Fracture of the radius is rare.

questions.question: A 22-year-old playing rugby fell awkwardly after being tackled, landing on his outstretched left arm, and experienced immediate pain in his forearm and elbow. He arrives at the emergency department with intense pain and is unable to flex or extend his elbow. Based on the X-ray findings, which type of Bado's classification does this injury represent?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Type II Explanation: The described scenario of a Monteggia fracture with posterior dislocation of the radial head falls under Type II of Bado’s Classification. Bado’s Classification Type Description Seen in Image Type I (Extension Type) (Option A) Anterior dislocation of the radial head with anterior angulation. Children (more common) Type II Posterior dislocation of the radial head with posterior angulation. Adults (more common) Type III (Option C) Lateral dislocation of the radial head Exclusively in children Type IV (Option D) Anterior dislocation of the radial head and fractures of both the radius and ulna occur at the same proximal level. Exclusively in adults

questions.question: A 30-year-old female slipped while demonstrating an exercise in a fitness class, landing on her outstretched right arm. She arrives at the emergency department with severe pain in her right wrist and forearm. Upon examination, her wrist appears unstable. Based on the X-ray findings, which of the following statements is true regarding her condition?

options.D: Posterior interosseous nerve is commonly involved

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Fracture of necessity Explanation: The presented scenario with the radiograph indicates a Galeazzi fracture, also known as a Piedmont fracture, a fracture of necessity (requiring surgery) , and a reverse Monteggia fracture, characterised by the distal third of the radius associated with a dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint . Galeazzi fracture Aetiology It is more common in adults. Three times more common than Monteggia fracture (Option C) Mechanism Fall on an outstretched hand (marked pronation of the forearm). Direct

A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department after falling while carrying a heavy load. Upon examination, he exhibits swelling, tenderness over the distal radius, and limited wrist motion. An X-ray is shown below. Which of the following statements about this condition is not true?

options.A: Fall on an outstretched hand with the wrist flexed
options.D: Involves volar displacement of the distal radius

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Managed with a "handshake" cast. Explanation: The scenario and X-ray depict a Smith fracture, also known as a Reverse Colles fracture , which involves a fracture at the distal end of the radius . A Handshake cast is typically used for a Colles fracture, not Smith’s fracture. Smith fracture or Reverse Colles fracture Site Involves the distal end of the radius with volar displacement of the distal fragment (opposite to a Colles fracture). (Option D) Mechanism It occurs due to a fall on an outstretched hand with a flexed wrist , leading to ventral displacement and tilting of the distal fragment. (Option A) X-ray Shows a tilted or displaced distal fragment at the radius. Management Closed reduction followed by above-elbow plaster of Paris (POP) immobilisation in extension for six weeks. Open reduction using an Ellis plate (if closed reduction is unsuccessful). Complications Garden Spade Deformity : Characterized by a prominent dorsal bulge and a flexed wrist position. (Option B)

questions.question: A 25-year-old male presents to the emergency department after falling on an outstretched hand during a sports activity. He complains of pain and swelling in his wrist, with tenderness in the anatomical snuffbox. X-ray imaging reveals a fracture of a carpal bone. What is the most common site of this fracture, and which part is most at risk for avascular necrosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Waist, Proximal pole Explanation: The clinical presentation and X-rays suggest a scaphoid fracture , with the waist of the scaphoid being the most common site, accounting for 70-80% of cases. Due to its limited blood supply from the distal portion, the proximal pole is at higher risk for avascular necrosis. Scaphoid fracture Site Waist of scaphoid (most common) (Option D) Distal pole (Least common) Proximal pole

questions.question: Match the following fractures with their site : 1. Mallet finger a) Comminuted fracture of base of the 1st metacarpal 2. Jersey's finger b) Neck of the 5th metacarpal 3. Rolando fracture c) Oblique fracture of base of the 1st metacarpal 4. Bennett fracture d) Rupture of the extensor tendon at the base of the distal phalanx 5. Boxer's fracture e) Rupture of distal end of flexor digitorum profundus of index finger
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 1-d, 2-e, 3-a, 4-c, 5-b Explanation: Fracture Description Image Mallet finger (Baseball finger) A sudden passive flexion of the distal interphalangeal joint (DIP) causes the extensor tendon at the base of the distal phalanx to be avulsed from its insertion. Treatment: Immobilize the DIP joint (Aluminium splint or plaster cast). Jersey's finger It is caused by sudden hyperextension of the distal joint, leading to avulsion of the flexor digitorum profundus tendon . This injury may result in either a rupture of the tendon or the detachment of a small bone fragment. Rolando fracture A comminuted (3 parts) articular fracture (‘T' or 'Y' shaped) of the base of the first metacarpal. Treatment: Reduction and fixation with K-wires, followed by immobilisation in a thumb spica for 3 weeks. Bennett fracture Oblique intra-articular fracture (2 part) of the base of the first metacarpal with subluxation of the metacarpal. It is caused by a longitudinal force applied to the thumb. Treatment: Closed reduction and percutaneous K-wire fixation Open reduction and internal fixation Boxer's fracture Fracture through the neck of the metacarpal (commonly the 5th metacarpal). Cause: Closed fist hits against a hard object Treatment: Mostly conservative

questions.question: A 28-year-old male presents with severe wrist pain after falling while playing tennis. Upon examination, there is swelling and tenderness on the ulnar side of the wrist, along with difficulty gripping. An X-ray is taken. What is the most likely diagnosis?

questions.question: Which of the following combinations of fracture and commonly injured nerves are correctly matched? a) Monteggia fracture - Posterior Interosseous Nerve b) Shaft of humerus fracture - Radial nerve c) Supracondylar fracture - Anterior Interosseous Nerve d) Hook of Hamate fracture - Deep branch of ulnar nerve
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) a,b,c,d Explanation: Fractures & Common Nerves Injured: Shoulder dislocation Axillary nerve Humeral shaft fracture Radial nerve Supracondylar Humerus fracture Median (mainly Anterior Interosseous nerve ) Holstein–Lewis fracture Radial nerve Elbow medial condyle Ulnar Nerve Monteggia fracture Posterior interosseous nerve Hook of Hamate Fracture Deep branch of Ulnar nerve Lunate Dislocation Median nerve Hip dislocation Sciatic nerve Knee dislocation/Neck of Fibula Fracture Peroneal nerve Reference: Apley and Solomon’s System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th Edition, Page 735,784

questions.question: A 3-week-old infant is brought to the clinic with a noticeable head tilt, as shown in the image. On examination, a firm mass is palpated in the neck region over the sternocleidomastoid muscle. Which of the following statements about this condition is not true?

options.A: It is more common on the right side of the sternocleidomastoid.
options.B: The Head is tilted towards the same side as the affected muscle.
options.C: The mass is often localised near the clavicular attachment.
options.D: The mass typically attains maximum size by 1-2 years of age.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) The mass typically attains maximum size by 1-2 years of age. Explanation: The given clinical scenario of a child with a tilted head and a mass over the sternocleidomastoid points towards Congenital torticollis. The mass typically reaches maximum size within 1-2 months , not years. Congenital Torticollis (Wry Neck): It is characterised by the contraction of the sternocleidomastoid muscle (SCM), which fails to elongate as the child grows, causing the head to tilt to one side while the face turns to the opposite side.

questions.question: A 6-month-old child with a noticeable head tilt is found to have a mass over the sternocleidomastoid muscle. The clinician is considering potential secondary deformities that may develop due to the condition. Which of the following deformities is most commonly associated with the condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Plagiocephaly Explanation: The child's presentation with the head tilt and mass over the sternocleidomastoid suggests Congenital Torticollis . Plagiocephaly, characterised by an asymmetrical head shape, is commonly associated with congenital torticollis due to the child's consistent head position. Deformities associated with Congenital Torticollis: These features worsen & become more evident as the child grows. Cervicothoracic Scoliosis (Option C) may be rarely associated with Congenital Torticollis. Kyphosis

questions.question: A 5-month-old child presents with a persistent head tilt to the right. The clinician suspects possible congenital torticollis and considers possible associated syndromes. Which of the following syndromes is least likely to be associated with congenital torticollis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Marfan syndrome Explanation: While Marfan syndrome can lead to musculoskeletal issues due to its effects on connective tissue, it is not commonly associated with congenital torticollis. Congenital Torticollis (CT) is caused by fibromatosis within the sternocleidomastoid muscle and often resolves within a year. It may lead to permanent muscle fibrotic changes and torticollis if not treated. Clinical Associations: It is frequently associated with difficult deliveries and other musculoskeletal disorders, including: Metatarsus adductus Developmental dysplasia of the hip Congenital Talipes equinovarus (CTEV) Congenital dislocation of the hip (7-20%) Syndromes Associated with Congenital Torticollis: Grisel Syndrome (Option B) refers to atlantoaxial rotatory fixation, where the atlas (C1) is displaced on the axis (C2), resulting in a fixed head position similar to the head tilt seen in torticollis. It often occurs after nasopharyngeal infections, tonsillectomy, or retropharyngeal abscesses. Down’s Syndrome (Option D): Children with Down syndrome often have atlantoaxial instability, which can lead to torticollis due to laxity in the transverse ligament and associated bony anomalies. Morquio Syndrome (Option A) is a skeletal dysplasia that can lead to cervical spine abnormalities, including basilar invagination and odontoid anomalies. These conditions may cause mechanical instability or neurological impairment, resulting in torticollis. Klippel Feil Syndrome involves the congenital fusion of at least two cervical vertebrae, most commonly in the upper cervical spine. This fusion restricts neck mobility and can lead to compensatory movements, resulting in torticollis. Also associated with sprengel deformity.

questions.question: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the pediatric clinic with a noticeable head tilt to the left and a firm, palpable mass in the right sternocleidomastoid muscle. The parents report that the child favours turning the head to the left and seems uncomfortable. Which of the following management strategies is most appropriate for this child's condition?

options.A: Immediate surgical intervention to prevent secondary deformities
options.B: Regular stretching exercises and physical therapy
options.C: Observation alone, as it resolves spontaneously
options.D: Use of a cervical collar to restrict head movement

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Regular stretching exercises and physical therapy Explanation: For infants < 1 year , conservative management is recommended. Regular stretching and physical therapy can help improve muscle length and function, facilitating recovery. Management of Congenital Torticollis: Spontaneous resolution : Most children improve without intervention. Conservative Management: (For Infants < 1 Year) Manual stretching by tilting the head towards the opposite shoulder. Early intervention (before 3-4 months) leads to excellent outcomes (92% to 100% achieving full rotation). Simply observing without intervention is not advisable (Option C). Surgical Intervention: If Congenital Torticollis persists beyond one year or after six months of physical therapy, surgical correction may be necessary (Option A) . Surgical techniques: Unipolar release: An incision is made near the clavicle, releasing the muscle at its inferior ends. Bipolar release (Ferkel’s Operation): The sternocleidomastoid muscle is released at both ends to provide more comprehensive correction. Complications of Surgery: Injury to Spinal accessory nerve & carotid bulb. Use of a cervical collar to restrict head movement (Option D) is not advisable in this case as it may lead to further complications and does not address the underlying muscle tightness. Reference: Campbell’s Operative Orthopaedics, 14th Edition, Page 1235,1236
